greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = n^2 if n^2 is the sum of two primes, otherwise a(n) = 0.
comment: For odd n, n^2 is odd so the two primes must be opposite in parity. Lesser prime must be 2 and greater prime must be n^2-2. Thus for odd n, n^2 is the sum of two primes iff n^2-2 is prime.
link: Harvey P. Dale, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
example: a(1) = 0 because the sum of two primes is at least 4 and a(11) = 0 because 11^2 - 2 = 119 = 7*17 is composite.
mathematica: stpQ[n_]:=If[OddQ[n],PrimeQ[n^2-2],AnyTrue[n^2-Prime[Range[ PrimePi[ n^2]]], PrimeQ]]; Table[If[stpQ[n],n^2,0],{n,60}] (* The program uses the AnyTrue function from Mathematica version 10 *) (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Jul 21 2018 *)
results.author: _Alexandre Wajnberg_, May 08 2005
ext: Edited and extended by _Klaus Brockhaus_ and _Ray Chandler_, May 12 2005
